Summary: CM for 14.3. Fresh snow above 500m although not expected to be significant. Old snow is firm and stable throughout. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Sparse snow cover mostly bare ground. Winds approx 10 - 20 mph fresh, cooling. Good visibility.
Comment: The hills will look wintry with fresh snow overnight but this will be mostly superficial.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight, showers falling as snow above 500 metres, dry thereafter. Fresh, North-West winds initially, veering North-Easterly through the night and decreasing to become light by the end of the forecasting period. The freezing level will drop to around 500 metres overnight and then rise steadily to 800 metres during the day.
SnowStability: There will be fresh snow above 500 metres although quantities are not expected to be significant. The old patchy snowpack will be firm and stable in all locations and will be mostly confined to steep North to East aspects above 950 metres. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mostly dry day with moderate Northerly winds. The freezing level was around 650 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: There is a light dusting of fresh snow above 700 metres. The old patchy snowpack is firm and stable in all locations being mostly confined to steep North to East aspects above 950m. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: NC for 14.3. Isolated unstable windslab SE,S,SW above 900 metres. Cornices. Stabilising later.
SnowDistribution: Deep snow on the plateau. Knee deep in isolated drifts. Whiteout conditions presenting some good navigation practice. Winds generally around 20mph.
Comment: A period of snow showers overnight are expected to result in rapid windslab accumulation in isolated locations.
WeatherInfluences: Snow showers are expected thought much of the period above 600 metres, with some reaching lower levels. Winds will be North-Westerly strong overnight, veering to the North-North-East and increasing to very strong for a time. The freezing level will be around 600 to 700 metres.
SnowStability: Isolated unstable windslab will develop on South-East to South-West aspects above 900 metres, during a period of snowfall and drifting overnight. Accumulations will initially exhibit weaknesses in steep wind sheltered locations, such as coire rims and gully tops, although these weaknesses are expected to diminish later. Elsewhere a fresh dusting of snow will be present from around 400 metres upwards in the morning. Small cornices will also develop. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Overnight showers continued into the afternoon, falling as snow above 500 metres, later 800 metres. Winds were generally from the North-North-West and moderate in strength. The freezing level was around 650 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack was observed to be generally stable with the greatest snow cover above 700 metres. Deeper accumulations of snow are present on South-East to South-West aspects above 1000 metres due to snow drift. A fresh dusting of snow was present from around 400 metres upwards in the morning, which was subject to thaw later, particularly on slopes exposed to the sun. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: TO for 14/3. Thin cover of stable snow. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Thin snow cover mainly above 700 metres.  Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells. Winds approx 10 - 20 mph.
Comment: Remaining dry for the next few days and becoming warmer through the weekend.
WeatherInfluences: Light showers in the early part of the night will fall as snow above around 500 metres then clear to give a dry day. Moderate, mainly Northerly winds will decrease in strength through the day. The freezing level will rise to around 800 metres.
SnowStability: Little change is expected. New snow deposits overnight are not expected to be significant. There will be a thin covering of stable snow on most aspects above 700 metres. A gradual thaw will take place during the day particularly on slopes exposed to the sun.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mainly dry day with occasional light showers which were snow above around 500 metres. Moderate North-Westerly winds. The freezing level was around 700 metres at midday rising slightly in the afternoon.
ObservedSnowStability: There is a thin cover of stable snow on most aspects, mainly above 700 metres. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: SC 14.03 Isolated unstable windslab in wind sheltered locations on SE to SW aspects above 900m. Avalanche hazard - Moderate.
SnowDistribution: Mostly shallow snow, occasional deeper drifts. No visibility above 900m. 10-20 mph winds - Chilly!
Comment: Expecting the higher Northern boundary mountains to receive more snow than the rest of the forecast area.
WeatherInfluences: Light snowfall overnight followed by a dry day. Moderate North-Westerly winds during the evening, increasing to strong North-North-Easterly by morning, then easing through the day. 700 metre freezing level, lowering to 500 metres overnight, returning to 700 metres by the end of the period.
SnowStability: Light snowfall and drifting will form windslab in wind sheltered locations on South-East to South-West aspects above 900 metres. Accumulations will be limited in distribution but where they achieve depth, especially over the old snow-ice, they will be unstable. The vast majority of terrain will have insignificant, shallow cover.  The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Light, intermittent snow showers on strong, easing to fresh, generally Northerly winds. Freezing level around 600 metres.
ObservedSnowStability: There is a general thin covering of fresh snow over bare ground above 600 metres. The old snow patches are firm and icy.  Isolated, deeper accumulations of snow are present in wind sheltered locations on South-East to South-West aspects above 900 metres. These deposits are starting to achieve depth but distribution is limited.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: GC for 14/3 A trace of new snow above 500m. Older patches of refrozen, icy snow on N to E aspects above 800m. Avalanche Hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: Patches of refrozen, firm and often icy snow exists above 800 metres. A trace of newer snow lying mostly on bare ground above 900 metres. Good visibility. Northerly winds approx 5mph to 15mph.
Comment: New snow deposit will likely thaw particularly at lower elevations as warmer conditions and freezing levels rise during the day. Paths will likely remain frozen and icy.
WeatherInfluences: The freezing level will fall to around 550 metres by the early hours of the morning then rise just above 800 metres by the end of the day. A trace of new snow is expected to fall during the night mainly above 500 metres. Winds will be moderate to fresh mostly from the North-East.
SnowStability: Light snow showers arriving with moderate Northerly winds, new accumulations will lay mostly on bare ground  and are not expected to be deep or extensive. Older snow patches will also remain on North to Easterly aspects particularly in sheltered hollows, gullies and steep coire rims these will be frozen, firm and often icy. Snow stability is expected to be good in all locations. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: The overnight the freezing level was around 200 metres this slowly rose to around 600 metres by the end of the day. It felt quite chilly today, the Northerly winds had quite a bite to them, it was dry and quite calm with good visibility.
ObservedSnowStability: A trace of snow and some rime ice is present mainly on North to East aspects above 900 metres. These amounts are not deep or significant and mostly lie on bare ground. Older snow patches also remain on similar aspects particularly in sheltered hollows, gullies and steep coire rims these are frozen, firm and often icy. Snow stability is  good in all locations. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: LO for 14/3. Cold and dry. Little change. The patchy refrozen spring snowpack will be hard, icy and stable. Low hazard.
SnowDistribution: Sparse snowpack with a dusting of soft snow at high levels.  Good visibility.  Winds 20 -30 mph easing through the day.
Comment: The old snowpack not extensive, but where does remain it is very hard and icy.
WeatherInfluences: North-Easterly winds will ease through the period. After a few light snow showers overnight it will be a dry day. The freezing level will be around 500 metres.
SnowStability: Little change is expected. The snowpack will remain hard, icy, patchy and stable. The greatest deposits will be found in high North to East facing gullies and coires. Any fresh deposits overnight will not be significant. The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It remained dry but a cloudy day with the freezing level around 700 metres. Northerly winds eased through the day.
ObservedSnowStability: The patchy old snowpack is refrozen and generally stable. There is a slight dusting of fresh snow above about 900 metres, but nowhere is this significant. The avalanche hazard is Low.
